docs.lead_paragraph: On its home turf in western Pennsylvania, the Silver Ring Thing is just one among many faith-based groups devoted to encouraging teenagers to avoid sex before marriage. Yet here in Britain, on its first overseas tour, the Silver Ring Thing's message of chastity has pitched the group into the center of a national debate on teenage sexuality and its attendant problems, on the efficacy of school-based sex education programs, and on the perceived American tendency to moralize.

headline.main: A Plea for Chastity, but Will It Play in Randy Britain?

docs.abstract: About 30 members of Silver Ring Thing, American teenage group whose members pledge not to have sex before marriage, take their message to Great Britain, country with some of highest rates of teenage pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases in Europe; are met with some skepticism from Britons who feel abstinence produces ignorance about sex and sexually transmitted diseases or who are suspicious of Americans moralizing to others; sponsors of two-week tour and some parents and clerics welcome message; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Woman's Guide to Living with H.I.V. Infection,'' by Dr. Rebecca A. Clark, Dr. Robert T. Maupin Jr. and Dr. Jill Hayes Hammer. Johns Hopkins University Press, $15.95. Early in the AIDS epidemic, men were thought to be at higher risk for the disease. Today, about half the adults living with H.I.V. or AIDS worldwide are women. In the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, about 12,000 women are infected every year, 30 percent of all new cases.
docs.abstract: Drs Rebecca A Clark, Robert T Maupin Jr and Jill Hayes Hammer book Woman's Guide to Living with HIV Infection uses series of questions and answers to address concerns about HIV infection that are specific to women; almost half of all HIV infected people worldwide are women and, according to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, women represent 30 percent of all new cases in United States; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the uglier aspects of the Bush administration's assault on women's reproductive rights is its concerted undermining of the United Nations Population Fund based on the false accusation that it supports coerced abortions in China. The fund supports programs in some 141 countries to advance poor women's reproductive health, reduce infant mortality, end the sexual trafficking of women and prevent the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS. Yet under pressure from conservative religious groups, the administration is expected to withhold the $34 million that Congress appropriated this year for these vital efforts, much as President Bush blocked the $34 million Congress approved in 2002 and last year's $25 million allocation.
docs.abstract: Editorial assails Bush administration for assault on women's reproductive rights; cites perpetuation of 'bogus accusation' that United Nations Population Fund has either stood by or helped with coerced abortions in China; says targeting of fund is attack on comprehensive family planning and women's sexual and reproductive autonomy driven largely by 'right-wing ideologues' opposed to all forms of family planning and contraception

docs.lead_paragraph: THE shoe is no beauty. With its thick, convex sole, it looks like something designed for Elton John in a sporty mood. And the name, Masai Barefoot Technology, is a doozy. You can't play basketball or tennis in it. Running at top speed is probably not a good idea either. Even climbing a flight of stairs can be tricky. But the MBT, as it's called, sells like hot cakes in Europe, and now it has found a toehold, so to speak, in the United States, where it has been a sellout item in the Bliss spa catalog, thanks to its billing as ''the anti-cellulite sneaker.'' Cellulite was not on the original agenda of the MBT's creator, Karl Müller, a Swiss engineer, who developed it as a way to relieve joint pain. Named in tribute to the long-striding Masai of East Africa, the MBT has been sold in Switzerland and Germany as a quasi-medical product. But in Britain a health writer named Harriet Griffey changed all that. She tried a pair and, in The Times of London, wrote that simply by wearing them and going about her daily rounds, she saw her cellulite disappear as if by magic. Under the headline ''Cellulite Busters,'' the article created a whole new identity for the shoe. A cult was born.
docs.abstract: William Grimes Just Browsing column describes trying out pair of Masai Barefoot Technology shoes, created by Swiss engineer Karl Muller, on streets of New York; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am pro-choice. But Garry Wills's argument that the Catholic Church can't legitimately have a position on abortion is absurd (''The Bishops vs. the Bible,'' Op-Ed, June 27). It is appropriate that a religion have a view on when life begins and whether the taking of life is ever justified. And Mr. Wills's comparison of a fetus to fingernail or hair clippings is an insult not only to abortion opponents but also to women who face the agonizing decision about whether to terminate an unwanted pregnancy.
docs.abstract: Michael Vatis letter responds to Gary Wills June 27 Op-Ed article; holds that his argument that Catholic Church cannot legitimately have position on abortion is absurd

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: New Haven Line riders are painfully aware of problems on our line: late trains, hot and dirty cars, broken seats, overcrowding (''The Stepchild of Metro-North?,'' June 20). But I'd like to raise a much deeper problem that became painfully clear to me on a recent Monday. It was a blistering hot June day and the air-conditioning was broken on part of the 7:59 express to Grand Central.
docs.abstract: Amy Liebesman letter on June 20 article about problems on New Haven line notes no male commuter on 7:59 train offered her seat when she was pregnant

docs.lead_paragraph: Blossom Mitchell is a 23-year-old mother of 1-year-old twins, and the transplanted heart she has is failing. She is at the top of the list to receive a new heart at the Westchester Medical Center here, but she faces a new challenge: the financially beleaguered hospital is suspending its heart and pancreas transplant units. And on Friday, with a strand of yellow rosary beads wrapped around her wrist, Ms. Mitchell was transferred to Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

headline.main: Patients Are Stunned as Hospital Halts Transplants in Westchester

docs.abstract: Fifteen patients awaiting heart transplants at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, NY, are stunned to learn that hospital is closing heart transplant program; are given two days' notice that they will be placed in other programs around New York State; closing is part of plan to make hospital profitable by 2006; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A pregnant Staten Island woman stabbed her husband to death early yesterday and then slit her wrists in their bedroom, the police said. She later gave birth to a healthy son by emergency Caesarean section. Last night, the police charged the woman, Sung-Ann Choi-Lee, 28, with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon. Her husband, identified as Matthew Lee, 30, was pronounced dead when police officers found him in the couple's house on Bay Street in Shore Acres at 7 a.m., the police said.

headline.main: Woman Kills Husband and Gives Birth, Police Say

docs.abstract: Sung-Ann Choi-Lee is charged with stabbing her husband to death and then slitting her wrists at home in Staten Island; later gives birth to healthy son by emergency Caesarean section (S)
